ANNE BOLEYN. A Crowned Falcon. Device of Anne Boleyn.

NOTE. Whether Anne Boleyn was guilty or not of the sins with which she was charged is of little moment. Minion of the brutal tyrant, she stepped into the place of her injured queen and mistress — this was the Nemesis that laid her head upon the block. There was more noble ness in her dying than in her living. THE AUTHOR.

DRAMATIS PERSONÆ. Henry VIII. Cardinal Wolsey. Duke of Norfolk. Earl of Surrey. Gardiner, Bishop of Winchester. Lord Beauchamp. Lord Ferrers. Lord Percy. Sir Thomas Boleyn, afterwards Earl of Wiltshire and Ormond. George Boleyn, afterwards Lord Rochford, his son. Sir Thomas Wyatt. Sir Thomas Audley. Sir William Kingston, Lieutenant of the Tower. Cromwell, Secretary to Wolsey. Norreys. Weston. Smeaton, a young musician. Nobles, Pages, Attendants, Ushers, Guards, Huntsmen, etc. Anne Boleyn. Lady Boleyn. Lady Rochford. Lady Kingston. Ladies, etc.

ANNE BOLEYN. ACT I. Scene I. — Ante-chamber in the Palace. Enter Earl of Surrey and Sir Thomas Wyatt from either side. Sur. Welcome, Sir Thomas Wyatt, welcome to Court. Last eve we missed your presence at the revels That graced York House. 'Twas a rare spectacle. Wy. I have lost much by my untoward absence. Sur. I'faith ! the daintiest mumming I have seen Since the encounter on the field of Ardres. Wy. I hear the King stole on the merriment In quaint disguise. Sur. His grace was in rare humour ; Jesting with Wolsey, mingling with the guests, As he had been of their like quality ; B

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act I 2 Treading gay measures with the fairest dames ; Whispering soft sayings in their willing ears, That called anon the colour to their cheeks. But chief he did affect the fairest there, The queenly rose amid the paler flowers, The moon amid the fainter constellations ; And when his grace broke up the revels, called For loving cup to quaff to her fair health, Whose beauty he proclaimed "queen of the feast." Wy. 'Tis said his grace looks coldly on his consort — Talks of his conscience and appeal to Rome. Prithee the name of this divinity? Sur. Who should it be, but my fair cousin Anne. Wy. Anne Boleyn? Sur. . Ay ! methinks that I have seen Some verse of Wyatt's muse that did rehearse The lady's praise. Wy. In wantonness of youth And youthful poesy, I do confess (And that our sires' estates adjacent lie), I did proclaim her mistress of my thoughts. That thus I sang her charms, and that she smiled To hear them sung, sole dalliance e'er passed 'Twixt us. She is troth-plighted to Lord Percy. Sur. Troths have been broken ! I would not the King Should smile too warmly on my lady-love. I would not have him whisper in her ear

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 3 Soft sayings, that call up enamoured glances. Wax that stands too much i' the sun may melt And lose its impress. Wy. Fie, my lord of Surrey ! The lady is most virtuous. Sur. Granted ! A woman still, and prone to change ; beauteous, Therefore ambitious. Since Eve plucked the fruit Of knowledge, the sex longs for things forbidden. Kings are not common suitors, woo like gods In golden showers. Not of flowers that wreathe The shepherd's crook, weave they the coronals To deck their mistress' brow, but of bright gems, Rival night's radiant stars ; pipe not their praise On slender reed, but with the clarion voice Of empire and renown. Such tempting baits The devil oft employs to lure faint heart From true allegiance. Wy. Tush ! there are eyes Would spy spots i' the perfect sun, could they Look into it. Sur. Anne too hath a fair spice Of vanity, that seasons woman's beauty. Of nature variable, quickly moved To passion, sorrow, anger, smiles, and tears ; As storms, clouds, heat, cold, tempests, wind and rain, All change that goes to make the heavens above us.

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act I. 4 Enter George Boleyn. Bol. Say, cousin Surrey, and Sir Thomas Wyatt, Ye were at last night's revels ; say ye then Did there aught chance for busy rumour's tongue To raise a cloud, as when a flock of sheep Travels o'er dusty roads ? Wy. I was a truant From the gay sports. Bol. Cousin of Surrey, speak. Sur. I was a guest of the Lord Cardinal. Bol. The King was there ? Sur. Ay, in disguise he came, Masked to the eyebrows, lest their lamps should scorch The foolish fluttering moths that danced too near The lightning glance of Jove. I never saw His grace in better humour. Blithe he danced, And for his partner chose the fairest there Of all the galaxy of beauteous dames. Beside her at the banquet took his seat, Nor from her presence could divorce himself, Till the sun showed his honest face i' the east- And, by my faith, he is no courtier To beauty after a night's heated revels. I ne'er saw his highness so bewitched With a bright glance.

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 5 Bol. Between a wedded king And a 'trothed damsel there is too much distance For such observance. Wy. You misjudge his grace. 'Twere hard that he should lack the privilege To look on beauty with admiring eyes. Bol. 'Tis noised abroad the King talks of his con science, And of divorcement from his royal consort. The Queen is ill at ease, and keeps her chamber. Sur. Women are subject to so many ills, Caprices, whims, disports, and fantasies, 'Tis hard to know when they most feign or feel. Wy. I scarce can think the King could entertain So bold a project, or e'er hope to win Consentment from the Holy See to such Disloyal act : to put aside his consort, A royal lady full of grace and goodness, Aunt to the Emperor But hold ! here comes His grace of York. Sur. He shows his fangs to-day. He frowns and bites his lip, an ominous sign. The Duke of Buckingham, poor gentleman, Paid for it with his head. He bears no love To any of our race. Whene'er I meet The butcher's son, I seem to feel his knife Already at my throat.

[Act I. 6 ANNE BOLEYN. Enter Cardinal Wolsey and Cromwell. Wol. (speaks as he enters). These papers will Unfold their purpose, — look that it be done. Crom. Your grace's orders shall be strict obeyed. [Exit. Wol. Never had man a truer servant Ha ! Your pardon, gentlemen ; I saw ye not. Sur. None are so blind as they who will not see ; So runs the adage. Wol. I pray ye be covered. I would not ye should catch a rheum, my lord For my poor sake. Sur. 'Tis fit the cap should doff In presence o' the hat, Lord Cardinal. We bow before the Church, not to her servant. Wol. And the Church thanks you now, my lord of Surrey, As her poor servant may hereafter. Sur. Poor ! Ye wrong yourselves by such a word. 'Tis long Since Churchmen doffed the garb of poverty. Clothed in purple now, they beard their sovereign, Ruling the nations with an iron hand. Wol. Surrey- Sur. Cardinal Wy. (aside to Surrey). Chafe him no further. Wol. Thy speech offends me not, unmannered boy.

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 7 My hair grown grey with care for England's weal Rebukes thy tongue. When thou hast served thy king As I have done, Wolsey will render thee Account of his high office. [Exit. Sur. By my faith, I honour him for the bold, keen rebuke. Let the curs snarl, Surrey will never more Bay his ascendant star. What say you now, Sir Thomas Wyatt, to a game at tennis ? Wy. With all my heart. Sur. Come on, then. [Exeunt Surrey and Wyatt. Bol. 'Tis full certain A perilous game, my lady mother plays ; And for our honour much I fear the issue, Enter Lord Percy. What, moody still ? Hast thou not seen my sister ? Per. I was denied admittance. Bol. How — denied ? Per. Attendance on the Queen was the dull plea. Bol. She bade thee later come ? Per. Ay ! on the morrow ; So said the page who brought her answer back To my petition for an interview. He said, " I might return upon the morrow." Were I a beggar who besought her alms, She might have sent a kinder.

[Act I. 8 ANNE BOLEYN. Bol. Words oft lose Their import, passing through another's lips, That speak not from the heart. Per. Her heart is changed. A royal suitor hath more potent charms At his command than youth and love. Bol. Hold ! Percy, Anne Boleyn is my sister. Per. For that cause I fain would deem her true. Bol. It might have been A message from my mother. Per. Yet would I Not enter i' the list 'gainst kings, lest I Should meet with arrant overthrow. Bol. What, jealous, I' faith? Come with me straight ; Anne Boleyn's smile Shall put thy angry doubts to sudden flight. [Exeunt. Scene II. — A room in the Palace. King ; Smeaton in the background. King. What is't but conscience weighs my spirits down, That should be joyous as a May-day morn? A brother's widow, faugh ! 'Tis a rank fault, For this lack I male issue to my bed,

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 9 Each bud with'ring ere it hath fairly blown. For this must England's golden sovereignty Upon a female brow descend ; the sceptre Turn to a distaff. What too if her birth Be a disputed point and she proclaimed Hereafter but a bastard of my line ? I must take note of this, Lord Cardinal. Anne Boleyn, sweet Anne Boleyn ! I could prattle Her name for ever, as babes lisp their mothers', Proud of their late-found speech. Sweet, sweet Anne Boleyn — 'Sdeath ! that I should love and find a hindrance ! Plainly I read the glance of her proud eye — It said, " To win me, I must be your queen." How daintily she would become a throne ! Methinks I see her seated at my side. Marry come up ! I were less than a king To be forbid to crown the mate I chose. Ha ! boy (to Smeaton), hast brought thy lute ? Smea. Sire, at your bidding. King. The Lady Anne did much commend thy voice Sing then, and we will judge its quality. Smeaton sings. The voice of pealing trumpet calls The warrior from his rest ; He clasps his hauberk on his breast, Rides forth his father's halls.

[Act I. 10 ANNE BOLEYN. 'Tis won, the well-fought battle-field Whose glorious hour were worth All other pleasures that on earth A thousand years might yield. King. Tush ! there are pleasures higher than the sport To knock one's neighbour on the pate, though some Still hold it as the aim and end of life, The boisterous game of war. Smea. Will't please ye hear How in the chase the royal hart was slain ? I know a moving ballad on the subject. King. Poor shallow mimicry of war, fit sport For boys to hunt the innocent hart to death. Smea. Hurt of hart's horn bringeth man to his bier, As I have heard, my liege. King. Hurt of hart's horn ! 'Tis the heart's hurt is dangerous, if love Heal not the hurt that beauty makes. Sing then Of love and beauty. Love, that hath ere this Made rocks and forests dance to his sweet piping ; Brought back the dead to life. Rare miracle, Hath softened hearts, withstood th' assault of death. Smeaton sings. Dark eyes, whence your dazzling light ? From the diamond flashing bright,

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 11 Or some jewel rich and rare? 'Tis the sun's beams sparkle there — Oh, then beware ! Blue eyes, whence your lovely hue ? From the violet wet with dew, Or the tint the sea-waves bear ? 'Tis heaven's smile that lingers there— Oh, then beware ! Dark eyes, blue eyes — 'tis the spell And power of love that in ye dwell ; — 'Tis love's light that sparkles there, 'Tis his charm that weaves the snare — Oh, then beware ! King. Go to ! thou art too young to sing love's praise ; Thou dost not sing like one distraught with love. Give me thy lute ; (twangs the strings) 'tis out o' tune. Enter Wolsey (unobserved). Wol. (aside). The King Jangling a lute like any wanton page ! It minds me of a sight that once I saw At the full tide o' the fair at Barthelmy, When a rough bear, mounted on his hind legs, Danced a round stave to the clown's dolorous fiddling. I was an urchin then. (Advances.)

[Act I. ANNE BOLEYN. 12 King. My lord of York (To Smeaton.) Leave us. [Exit Smeaton. Oh, I am sick at heart, my Wolsey. O conscience, conscience ! what a wretch thou mak'st Of sinful man, plucking the rose of peace From out his thoughts, planting a canker there. What comfort dost thou bring thy king, my Wolsey ? Wol. A messenger from Rome hath just arrived King. Well, well, his news, man — what of the divorce ? Wol. I pray, your highness, exercise some patience. King. Patience ! 'tis the same sermon ye have preached These six months past. I've lived on't — patience, patience ! My sole aliment, ay, food, wine, sleep, sport — I've fed on't to a surfeit. Wol. The Pope's scruples, Sire King. When did his conscience wax so tender ? Scruples ! He hath pronounced divorce ere this Between two loving hearts, for some slight flaw F the marriage contract, light as feather I' the scale ! He weighs the Emperor's frown Against our wish, and when the balance sinks, Calls his tremors scruples. Scruples forsooth ! Wol. Cardinal Campeggio is on his way To England, with a Brief touching the matter.

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 13 The Holy Father counsels your grace, meanwhile, To take the Queen back to your royal favour, To live as should become a loving pair The Church hath joined in holy wedlock. King. Ah ! Cleanse this marriage bond from leprous taint And I would ask no better ! Were I free To wed once more, Katharine of Arragon Should still be queen of Henry — but this conscience, The shadow of our sinful wakeful thoughts, That will not let us sleep o' nights ! — Hast thou Spoken with the boy Percy ? Wol. Ay, my liege, But with small shrift. Angry he grew, then sullen. I taxed him with his love for Mistress Anne — Bade him forego his suit, renounce the troth. I told him that your grace had other views For the young lady ; that he placed his hopes Too low, that might graft on a higher stem. King. You went too far ; the lady is of blood Might mate with kings, and they know no abasement. Wol. The Lord Northumberland, urged by my counsels, Hath made threats of disheritance will drive The folly from Lord Percy's shallow brain. King. Go to ! such folly we ourselves have dreamed Ere now. Wol. Oh, good my liege, bethink you well !

[Act I. 14 ANNE BOLEYN. Katharine of Arragon, your faithful consort For twenty years, the partner of your greatness, Mother of the young princess your sole heir ; Daughter of a king, aunt to the Emperor, A queen, may not be lightly thrust aside. King. This doctrine hath been preached till my ears tingle. 'Sdeath ! I would have male heirs to wear the crown When my head lies i' the dust, nor can hope For these, while I live on in sinful wedlock. I would not to a puling girl bequeath My kingdom, thus given o'er to foreign rule Or civil discord. For his people's good Henry alone now seeks divorce from her Who ever was the apple of his eye. Wol. Alack, my liege ! I fear me 'twill be said Your grace is less moved by your people's welfare, If so your virtuous queen be put aside To make room for a simple gentlewoman, Than love for Mistress Anne. King. More reverence, Lord Cardinal. There is small love, I wot, Between you and the lady ; ay, beshrew me, I've noted this. She doth affect new doctrines, That touch your Church's proud supremacy. I do mistrust thee, Cardinal. 'Sdeath ! man, I know thy towering ambition ; ay, Its aim and end to mount St. Peter's chair,

■5 Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. When next 'tis vacant ! For this thou wouldst rain o By meek compliance th' Emperor's good will, Crossing our wishes by thy subtle craft, Heaving up obstacles by thy false breath, Pleading a Churchman's vows for lack of zeal, Shelt'ring beneath the shadow of the Church Thy sly hypocrisy. Look to 't, Cardinal, For, by my halidome, I'll rule this realm Despite of Pope or Kaiser. More ado ! I'll make myself supreme head of the Church j Then let the Pope cry largesse for his pains ! Wol. My liege and lord, all that I am, I owe Your gracious favour — needs must stand or fall At your good pleasure. Sire, this all men know. Who, then, is foe to the divorce must needs Be foe to Wolsey. True, divorce obtained From your queen, Katharine, I could have wished Your grace's newer choice had fallen on one More near your rank and quality, my liege — ■ The Princess Re'ne'e, or the French king's sister, The Duchess d'Alengon. Such marriage bond Would be strong league of amity with France ; Would much import to England's greatness, and Your grace's comfort. King. If I choose to wed A kitchen wench, making her one with us, The King, I make her equal unto all, No matter of what quality. By'r faith,

16 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act I. We married once to please our sire and people, When next we wed Harry will please himself. [Exit. Wol. Talk of the tender pricks of consience ! 'tis A fair young face pricks his desire for change. A princess, Katharine of Arragon, Daughter of kings and emperors, a queen, Wife to a king, mother of a fair daughter Who shall be queen hereafter, to be thus Put aside to make way for a wanton ! (After a pause) Am I betrayed ? It cannot be ? All's safe ! 'Tis but the humour contradiction vents In the King's churlish mood. The tiger shows His claws and teeth e'en in his lightest gambols. On Wolsey's horizon I spy a cloud, That threatens to o'ertake his sun, ere yet It mount to full meridian ! This girl, This puppet Anne, would smile to my undoing. She knows not yet how light her suitor's fancy ; As shifting as the wanton winds, that blow From every quarter, as they list. Let her Maintain awhile the pinnacle of virtue, He'll soon grow weary. If she trust his oaths, Ay, but one hour too soon — I know him well — He'll cast her like a noisome weed away, His fancy being spent. No ! he may toy Awhile with Mistress Anne, but for his queen He shall espouse the Duchess d'Alencon.

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 17 Enter Duke of Norfolk, Surrey, Gardiner, Wyatt, and others. Gard. His grace is in his closet ; we will enter. Lord Cardinal, I pray ye, stand aside That we may pass. Wol. (aside). Ha ! is it come to this, That Wolsey must give way to Gardiner? Nor. (aside to Gardiner). Anger him not, my lord ; there's room to pass. Gard. Fear not ; we have our warrant, the King's pleasure. Wol. Now, Heaven forbid that Wolsey e'er should be Or let or hindrance to his gracious pleasure. My lords, I am not keeper of the door. [Exeunt Norfolk, Gardiner, and others. Why pass you not, Lord Surrey, with the rest? Sur. Go you not in, my lord of York ? we follow. Wol. Thy nature, noble Surrey, hath been formed To be the mirror of all courtesy And gentle thoughts, and deeds of high achievement. Take thou an old man's warning and learn wisdom, Which he hath not — until too late to learn. Beware ; walk ever charily at Court, Where brave men stumble oft. When cowards act A bold and open part, then most take heed. When ocean seems most calm, look out for shoals c

[Act I. 18 ANNE BOLEYN. i May wreck the bark trusts her deceitful smile. When the sky o'er thee bends most lovingly, Beware the bolt ! The summer cloud oft hides The murderous lightning in her fleecy bosom ; And crafty ruin oft with double face Turns her fair Janus-side to our undoing. Remember Wolsey's warning — and pass on. [Exeunt Surrey and Wyatt. Ha ! sent for to his presence, to his closet, While I am left to cool my humour here, Like a discarded lacquey ! Does he think To do without me then ? Not yet ! My will Is not yet blunted by satiety. My brain still teems with plans for England's weal ; These shoulders have not borne the weight of empire, To bend beneath a puny wisp of straw Mine enemies would lay upon them. Bubbles Blown from the mouth of children, to dissolve I' the air made them. No, not yet, not yet ! The sun of Wolsey shall not sink betimes, But o'er the firmament pursue its course To the full hour of setting. Night's pale orbs May twinkle to their utmost, the day done ! The King shall wed as I would have him, or He keeps his homely Kate to comfort him At bed and board. Prate of the stings of conscience Well, let him sing love ditties, twang a lute, Heave amorous sighs of passionate desire ;

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 19 His wanton arms fill o'er with empty reeds ; Gaze on Diana with Actæon's eyes — But for his mate no other shall he have Than the French princess, Duchess d'Alengon. [Exit. Scene III. — A room in the house of Sir Thomas Boleyn. Enter Anne Boleyn, with a book. Anne. The words flow pretty. 'Tis no mean verse That sings our praises. All is noted down : Eyes, hair, brow, cheek, my neck — what saith he here ? " Her neck, the silver beauty of the swan In hue and grace." The King did much commend it At my lord Cardinal's ; protested 'twas Worthy to wear a carcanet of price. Eyes, hair, brow, cheek — my neck, I never knew Till then it was so wondrous fair ! so slender One of my little hands can almost clasp it. Enter Sir Thomas Boleyn. Sir Thos. Come hither, Lady Anne, salute your father ! No longer plain Sir Thomas Boleyn, Knight, But Earl of Wiltshire and of Ormond. Anne. Sir ? Sir Thos. Wiltshire and Ormond — ay, your lady mother

[Act I. ANNE BOLEYN. 20 No more shall twit me with my plain descent : No more despise the coat of arms first borne By my good father, the late worthy mayor ; No more disdain the viands ; on our plate A coronet will tempt her appetite. I'll hear no more of her high ancestry, Her duchess-mother and the duke her sire, And all the noble race akin to her ; As if the Howards came into the world With cloth of gold upon their naked limbs. Countess of Wiltshire and of Ormond, now She styles herself. Anne. I am well pleased to learn Such welcome tidings, sir. Sir Thos. Call me " my lord ; ' 'Tis now my style. I am as much a lord As any Howard of them all, i'faith. Anne. The Queen's grace doubtless hath solicited The honour for us. Sir Thos. Humph ! I rather think 'Tis the King's grace that hath bestowed it, child. Here comes thy lady mother ; she can best Unfold the matter — humph ! Lady Bol. Come to my arms ! A crown would well become my Anne's fair brow. Sweetheart, dost look into thy mirror oft ? For beauty thrives, looking on its own image. That blush becomes thee, girl. I would the King

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 21 Could see thee now. My lord, hast told the damsel Of the high honour that his grace would show us ? Sir Thos. The chit lays all to the Queen's offices. Ha, ha ! a goodly jest. Lady Bol. The Queen ! Anne. Ay, madam. Since first I entered in her grace's service, She hath proved more a mother to me, than Strict mistress of my duty. Lady Bol. Go to, child ! Katharine of Arragon is fitter To be a cloistered nun than enthroned queen. The crown she would invoke for thee were like To be in heaven above. To the King's favour We are beholden more than thanks can pay. What book hast thou in thy hand ? Anne. Some verses Writ by Sir Thomas Wyatt. Lady Bol. Fie, girl, fie ! Love verses are not toys for maiden's thoughts. Throw them away, his highness would not choose That every idle gallant of the Court Should sing thy charms. Anne. What is it to the King If Wyatt list to sing a milkmaid's charms ? Lady Bol. His highness is of jealous temper, girl. Anne. He is no courtly beauty to be ruffled With envy at my praise. What is't to him ?

ANNE BOLEYN. ■ [Act I. 22 He cannot take my head off, that a minstrel Hath praised the beauty of my neck. It were Not plea enough to make Lord Percy frown. Lady Bol. Percy is but a peevish boy, my Anne Must learn now to forget. Anne. Forget Lord Percy ! What mean you, madam ? Sir Thos. Anne, why, look you now. 'Twere best you did forget him. Anne. My betrothed, My future lord — my Percy? Sir Thos. Anne, be patient. The Cardinal disproves the match. Anne. The Cardinal ! Let him look to the Church ; it needs his ruling, More than my poor heart. The Cardinal ! Forsooth, let him not meddle in such matters. Are we his subjects ? I will to the King. The Queen hath given consentment to the marriage ; The Lord Northumberland hath given consentment. There was a time ye knew no dearer wish Than to behold me Percy's wife — and now, Ye tell me to forget him ! Sir Thos. Anne, Anne, Anne ! Speak to her, madam, prithee, speak to her, And stay this violent tempest. Lady Bol. Anne, what if The King have higher views for thy advancement ?

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 23 Anne. The King can make a duke, if he so please ; The name of Percy needs not such advancement. Sir Thos. Thou art distraught with pride. Lady Bol. Leave me, my lord, To bring this headstrong girl to reason. Sir Thos. Ay, Listen to your lady mother. Lady Bol. Leave us, My lord, I pray. Sir Titos. Ay, listen to her, Anne. [Exit. Anne. What mean your looks, that shrink from mine — your silence ? I cannot bear it, madam — only speak. Lady Bol. Lord Percy hath forsaken thee. Anne. No, no, It cannot be ; this is some cozenage. Lord Percy is the soul of honour. Lady Bol. So Thinks every maiden of her lover. Girl, Thou hast to learn that woman's love, to man, Is but a stepping-stone to fortune's favour, Or the light toy of his fantastic hours. And she is wise who uses well the knowledge ; A man's low selfish nature makes a tool For her ambition. Anne. Percy loved me truly. Lady Bol. No marvel that he loved ! My Anne is fair.

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act I. 24 He loved thee, true ; one breath of fickle air, And lo ! his true love saileth to the moon. Anne. I cannot think 'tis so. Lady Bol. What, doubt thy mother ? I speak not without warrant — these the proofs : Thy betrothal ring, the lock of hair He should have garnered next his heart till death ; Thy letters are returned. Anne. My ring, my letters ! Some evil tongue hath slandered me to Percy. Lady Bol. Who loves is jealous — 'tis man's nature, true. But jealousy is subtle to discover Where the wind lies, lifts the light feather up Chance dropped upon the ground ; like the blind mole Gropes on to daylight. 'Tis not jealous)' — He hath broken troth with thee. Anne. I shall grow mad. Lady Bol. He plights his troth with Lady Mary Talbot, Ay, on this very day. Anne. In mercy kill me, Kill me ; bury me deep, deep in the earth Where never human eye shall see me more. I did so love this man. For him I joyed To know that I was fair, for him grew jealous, When others praised my beauty; wreathed with flowers,

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 25 The victim to be cast down i' the dust Beneath his scorn ! There is no future now For me on earth. Lady Bol. A glorious one ! Only Be counselled, Anne, by me. When love proves false, There is revenge. Anne. Revenge ! poor spite to love ! For all the world, love would not harm one hair Of the beloved one's head. Revenge is sweet To foes. My curse would be a blessing still On Percy. Lady Bol. Wouldst thou tamely bear the wrong ? Thy face was never meant to peak and pine For a false suitor. Thou wilt love and wed. Anne. Ah ! never will I trust man's vows again. Lady Bol. Some wed for love ; the wiser part for wealth, Ambition, power. Anne. Oh, hollow mockery ! Ambition for the heart that craves for love- Yet once I was ambitious. Lady Bol. Ay, hereafter Thou'lt bless thy stars for this mishap. What if The King should love thee ? Anne. His love were dishonour, Being already wedded. Much I marvel, Madam, that you should speak oft.

26 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act I. Lady Bol. He is wedded, True, but the Church hath power to loose such bonds. Knowing the Queen was first his brother's wife, He feels the stings of conscience, looks to have Divorce. Anne. Surely his grace would never think To do such wrong, as put away his queen, After so many years of faithful wedlock. Lady Bol Katharine hath lived more like a cloistered nun, Than joyed in her high state. Holy retirement Best suits her mood. My Anne would grace a throne. Anne. Oh, madam, speak not thus. If e'er Anne Boleyn Usurp the place 'pertains her royal mistress, May every woe fall on her guilty head. Enter Lord Rochford. Koch. What means this coil ? Men say the troth is broken Betwixt Anne and Lord Percy. Anne. In one hour My heart grew cold and hard as marble. Koch. Say, What doth it mean ? Lady Bol. Go ask the loyal Percy. Roch. Anne, he loves thee better than his life

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 27 Lady Bol. Yet weds the Lady Mary Talbot. See, Anne's jewels, letters are returned, as they Had been the proffers of some wanton. Anne. Rochford, The Cardinal's to blame. Roch. I fear one higher Than cardinal hath meddled here. Lady Bol. Well, well, What if the King designed a loftier rise For Anne ? Roch. A sudden rise foreshadows oft A speedy fall. Who soars too high must needs Know dizzier fall. Lady Bol. What if his grace should raise her To that great height whence there can be no fall, Even to himself ! Roch. He who is false to one Will ne'er be true to any. Trust him not. When time shall strip thy form and face of beauty, Another, young and fair, will minister To his polluted fancy. O my sister, If Katharine of Arragon e'en now Were in her grave, and thou couldst mount her throne Without an honest scruple, yet beware Of Henry's vows. I fain would save thee, Anne, From lot as cold and joyless as my own ; A marriage bond without or love or faith. Anne. That I should live to be a mocking word,

28 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act I. I for whose smile men have braved death ere now ! To be rejected thus ! Lady Bol. Think of her triumph, The homely daughter of Lord Shrewsbury, Decked in thy nuptial pomp, bearing the name Of Percy's wife, that should have been thine own. Anne. I shall go mad. Oh, Percy, Percy ! Lady Bol. Shame, To grieve for such a recreant ! It shames me That child of mine should own so poor a spirit. Avenge thyself. Roch. Proffer not evil counsels, Madam. Revenge ever recoils on him Who dallies with its weapons. Anne. Where is't — revenge ? Lady Bol. The King will seek thy hand ; ay, girl, the hand Lord Percy hath disdained. Ay, mark me, Anne, Thou shalt be Queen of England, so that thou Be governed by my counsels. Enter Duke of Norfolk, attended. Nor. Lady Anne, Marchioness of Pembroke, I salute you I' the King's name. Two thousand pounds each year To keep your state withal. Lady Bol. Say, was I not True prophet of your fortunes ?

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 29 Anne. Can it be, Or doth some evil spirit tempt me thus ? Marchioness of Pembroke ! Lady Bol. (aside to Anne). Command yourself. There is amaze to see you so distraught. (Aloud) My lord, I pray, o'erlook your niece's silence. Surprise has so amazed her senses, that She finds no words of thanks for this great honour. Anne. Too great an honour for so poor a subject ! I thank his grace. Nor. Marchioness of Pembroke ! Tut, tut ! has greater things behind. His grace Stints not his royal bounty. With his greeting, Here sends you a fair jewel for your neck, That once belonged unto his sainted mother, Elizabeth of York ; so prized, he ne'er Till now hath found one worthy to succeed To its inheritance. Lady Bol. The carcanet His grace is wont to wear around his hat At festivals, matchless in Christendom. There is no richer offering, save a crown. Anne. I am not worthy of so rare a jewel. I pray ye, take it back, good uncle Norfolk. Lady Bol. Fie, Anne ! reject his highness' gift ! My lord, I pray you, take no heed of these strange scruples, But maiden coyness all. (To Anne) Come, let me clasp

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act I. 30 The jewel round thy neck, to show how well The King hath chosen its adornment. See, My lord of Norfolk, think you not the gems Shine brighter for the whiteness of the neck They clasp so lovingly? Nor. Mine eyes are dazzled By the encounter. So, I will report Unto his grace's ear mine office done. [Exit, attended. Lady Bol. Come, look into the mirror ; feast thine eyes. Anne. Oh, quick undo the clasp ! I feel as if Some murderous hand were at my throat — the gems Red gouts of blood flowing adown my bosom. Roch. 'Tis not too late; reject the glittering bauble. The price which thou must pay is all too dear. Anne. Alack, alack ! what shall I do ? Lady Bol. Trust me, 'Tis not so difficult to mount a throne ! Give me thy hand, thou shalt be Queen of England, King Henry's wife. All knees shall bend to thee, Even the truant Percy. Come with me. [Exit, leading Anne. Roch. The bird ta'en captive i' the fowler's net As well may hope to 'scape as thou, my sister. The hour is fraught with ruin to our house. [Exit. end of act i.

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 31 ACT II. Scene I. — A room in the Palace. Enter Surrey- and Wyatt, meeting. Wy. My lord of Surrey, come you from the Council ? Sur. Ay, and right glad to 'scape it with my head Upon my shoulders still. I never saw The King so chafed with anger. Like a tiger He glared around, as if to choose his prey. At length his wrath broke forth in words. He charged His grace of York with plotting to delay The coveted divorce ; swore that no longer He would abide the Pope's tardy decision ; Abruptly then dismissed the trembling Council, And passing out, frowned on the Cardinal, Till Wolsey's flushed brow cowered beneath the menace. Men by this token read his coming downfall. Wy. He will rally yet, and drive his foes Out o' the field.

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act II. 32 Sur. Listen to the sequel. An intercepted letter to the Emperor, Writ by the Cardinal, beginning thus : " Ego et Rex meus," seals his ruin. Had ye seen the jackals, one by one, How they sluuk back, leaving the Cardinal, Like stricken lion, standing i' the midst Alone, you would have known his hour was come. Yet lion-like in port and bearing still He stood, facing his craven foes, till even The brazened Gardiner looked down abashed. When he departed, leaving to their mercy His name and reputation, they fell on't, As they had been a pack of famished wolves, Tearing it bit by bit, till not a shred Was left the hounds to gnaw at. E'en the ass Had a fling at him, who but yesterday Weighed out the sum of life and death. This Wolsey Owns many faults — among them arrogance, Disdain of lower men, pride, avarice ; Yet 'neath his governance hath England flourished, And none know I more worthy of his office. Wy. I cannot think the King will soon forget His long and zealous services. Sur. A feather Weighed 'gainst Anne Boleyn's smile ! She sees a crown Suspended o'er her head ; to reach the prize,

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 33 She must step o'er the prostrate Cardinal. Where once ambition enters, farewell pardon ! Wy. The sorrowing Queen, who weeps at Kim- bolton, Might read a lesson to ambition. Sur. Ay, Poor Queen ! she is most worthy of all pity. And mark me, Wyatt, we shall live to see The fair usurper Anne hurled from her seat. Wy. 'Tis said Cranmer will straight pronounce divorce Betwixt the King and Katharine ; e'en said His grace hath tarried not for Churchman's leave, But by a secret union hath already Forestalled his suit to Anne ; and to prepare Men's minds to look upon a loftier rise, She is created Marchioness of Pembroke, Two thousand pounds withal to keep her state Each year. I warrant me, Wolsey's full coffers Will pay for it. Enter Duke of Norfolk and Gardiner. Sur. (to Norfolk). A fair young niece you have, My lord and sire, that we may thank hereafter If still we keep our places i' the realm. She doth affect the Lutheran creed, and soon Will make England a nest of heretics, To plague the Pope withal. D

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act II. 34 Nor. Tut, tut, boy ; 'tis No time for jests. My lord of Winchester And I are on grave business bent. Sur. Bring ye Queen Katharine's crown to crown Queen Anne? If so, I would have ye crave a boon for Surrey. Nor. Tut, tut ! Our warrant doth concern his grace The Cardinal of York. Sur. Alack, poor Wolsey ! Is midnight come already, ere the day Hath sobered into twilight ? Pitchy midnight. No stars o'erhead ; when wolves steal on the fold In sheep's clothing. Now, when I hear thy name, Thy high and mighty titles, 'tis as if A herald o'er some mouldy vault rehearsed The style and title of a prince laid low, Wound up with echo of his broken bauble, To scare the worms withal. Gard. Think you, my lord, That we bear malice to the Cardinal ? Sur. Rancorous, deadly malice, my lord Bishop ! It flashes in your eye, flushes your cheek, Hurries your footsteps, quivers on your lips, And in your heart — I will not look within, Lest I should lose all Christian charity, Such as ye Churchmen preach in homilies,

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 35 But leave to laymen the plain practice. Nor. Surrey, Go con thy sonnets o'er — yet say, knowest thou Where Wolsey meditates upon his sins ? Sur. Wolsey ! what, come to this ? At morn it was My lord high Cardinal, his grace of York ! At noon, plain Wolsey ! By to-morrow, he Will be the butcher's dog that every cur May snarl at ! 'Tis the world's true proper fashion. I know not where his grace employs his time, But wheresoever the place, 'tis honoured ; ay, When we shall have returned to native dust, Leaving the world's stage to other players, Time shall crown Wolsey's name, while we perchance May be forgot. Gard. We dally here too long. We'll leave Lord Surrey to his oracles. Nor. Come on ; I would the business were complete. [Exeunt Norfolk and Gardiner. Sur. If that arch-bigot e'er have rule in England, Blood, blood alone, will quench the faggots he Will light i' the width and breadth o' the land. I'faith, I would not be a heretic Where Gardiner hath a voice o'er fire and stake ! Let us seek out the Cardinal. Yon pair Are the harsh screech-owls of his fate. I fain Would learn the sequel of his wondrous tale. [Exeunt Surrey and Wyatt.

36 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act II Scene II. — A room in the Palace. Enter Wolsey. Wol. Marchioness of Pembroke ! Anne, thy star Hath conquered ! Mine is waning fast, and men Shall look in vain henceforward for its place In th' heaven where once it shone pre-eminent. Who puts his faith in princes stamps his fortunes On the unstable sand, whence the rude sea Shall wash all trace away in its reflux. When I am gone, men shall say this of me : "He served his country well, preferring ever Her interests before his proper weal. Learning he did prefer to blustering valour, The pen before the sword ; a friend to learning, That makes good citizens and honest men." And so ends Wolsey's epitaph ! Enter Anne Boleyn. Anne (about to retire). My presence Shall not disturb your gracious meditations. Wol. Your presence, lady, is the gracious sun, Dispenseth light and comfort ; withdraw not. Thou thinkest Wolsey is thine enemy — Thou err'st. Thou wert to me, but the light moth That floats i' the garish sunshine, too fleeting To be crushed. Thy thoughts are thy arch-foe

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 37 And tempter. Yet take heed, take heed, Anne Boleyn ! The vulture's beak may gore the falcon's breast. The breath of prophecy sweeps o'er my soul, As oft will come, when hour of doom is nigh. We meet for the last time in earthly presence, Yet will I be near thee at the revel ; When the gay laugh is loudest, Wolsey's voice Shall ring in thy scared ears, like a death-knell. At banquet 'midst thy dames and courtiers, The ghost of thy past life shall rise before thee In shape of her, thy injured Queen, whose place, Thou hast usurped. Anne. Lord Cardinal ! Wol. Time's fingers The curtain of the future draw aside — Lo ! I behold a schism in the Church. Men shall dispute o'er words, rites, ceremonies ; Fight like keen gladiators, warmed with blood, Until they rend asunder all the ties That make men brethren; heaven and hell, man's conscience Confounding in one dire disorder ! Thou, Anne Boleyn, the frail cause and pretext be. Anne. You do outstrip your privilege of speech, Lord Cardinal. Yet would I from the King Implore your pardon. Wol. Thou ! thou sue for Wolsey ! Better attempt the lion in his den,

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act II. 38 Than beard the wrath of Henry ! Knowest thou, then, So little of the fate that thou wouldst tempt ? Never did Henry spare man in his anger, Nor woman in his desire. When thou'rt queen, Look well that none come near thee, save foul age, Ill-favoured visages, or crook-backed shapes ! Look well the lowliest menial of thy train Be of such shape and mien, rank jealousy Could ne'er suspect of favour in thine eyes ! Smile not on any, not on thine own kindred, Lest Henry's corrupt fancy deem it treason ! When, in despite of all thy pains, the 'King Shall look upon a fairer face than thine, Despair and die ; thine hour is come, Anne Boleyn ! Thou wilt be then alone, as I am now. All will fall off from thee, friends, kindred, lovers, Thy cringing courtiers, all will forsake thee, Whose crumbling fortunes may drag down to ruin. Anne. 'Tis too terrible ! take this curse from me, For such I feel it, O Lord Cardinal ! Wol. Wolsey wars not with such as thee, Anne Boleyn ; Leave me, the ministers of fate approach. [Exit Anne. Enter Norfolk and Gardiner. Nor. We come, Lord Cardinal of York — that is — The King hath sent us.

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 39 Wol. I await, my lords, His royal pleasure. Nor. (aside to Gardiner). Pray ye, speak to him, Wol. Have ye no words to do the King's high bidding ? I will withdraw till ye recover breath (going). Gard. Stay, Wolsey. Wol. . Gardiner ! Gard. In the King's name We here demand the seal of your high office. Wol. From the King's hand I took the seal, to him Will render it. Nor. Tut, tut, Lord Cardinal ; We have his grace's warrant. Wol. And ye have My answer. Gard. We will to the King report Wolsey's obedience — come, duke. [Exeunt Norfolk and Gardiner. Wol. Thus ends The term of all my greatness. Enter Cromwell. Behold now The gratitude of kings, my CromwelL Crom. Then Rumour spake truth, alack !

40 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act II. Wol. My faithful Cromwell, Truth is the shadow of adversity. She hath no flattery for evil fortune ; She hath no fables to puff up fallen pride, No soothing whispers for the troubled ear. Truth is no fawning courtier to hang Upon our skirts when we sink in the slough. Never doth she speak 'neath a palace roof, Save when a tyrant dies and leaves no heir. Beside the humble board she takes her seat, Teaching the poor, harsh lessons. Now will truth Pour her rough counsels in my chastened ear; For I am fallen from my high estate. Now doth the flimsy fabric of my greatness Fade from my purged vision into air. 'Twas but a mist, the sun's deceitful smile Turned to bright bow that melted into dew. Crom. Who would believe the sun so soon eclipsed, That shone with so great splendour, this old world Scarce knew a parallel ? Wol. Alas, my Cromwell ! Our fortunes oft flow smoothly, as the stream Glides 'twixt two level banks, until it reach The brink of some deep precipice, o'er which It madly plunges, whirling, foaming, down, Bearing the wrecks of our high hopes along. Our fortunes rise like swelling wave, that when It reach its bent, poises a while, then falls !

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 41 This seal, which o'er the realm was type and proof Of power illimitable and supreme, Is but a bauble in my nerveless grasp, In presence of the fair-faced puppet Anne. I prithee bear it to the King and make Thy peace with him, Crom. All that I am I owe Your grace ; life's service pays not my great debt I follow wheresoe'er thou goest. Wol. Not so ! Launch not thy future in my sinking bark. At Court thy honest zeal may serve me, if Remorse should e'er o'ertake the King's slow con- science, With memory of Wolsey's services. I trust my cause to thee and honest Time, That sets some things aright even in this world. Enter Lord Percy and Guards. Per. My lord, i' the King's name I here arrest you Wol. Thus retribution comes in guise of justice. I did you sometime wrong, Lord Percy, ay, Thwarting your love to please the King, and lo He sends me to the Tower. Per. Heaven forbid Your grace should lodge with traitors ! Good my lord, 'Tis the King's pleasure you withdraw a while To Esher, there to live in privacy.

[Act II, 42 ANNE BOLEYN. Wol. The King shall hear but little of his servant To vex his princely ear. I have no sword To render up ; yet have I served his highness As faithfully as any of his captains. Henceforth I've done with earthly cares and frets, Ta'en leave of the world's dusty blazonry, That blurs the painted canopy o'erhead With its misdeeds. My thoughts shall shape them selves Towards high Heaven in future, that my need Will e'er befriend, though it should greater grow. Commend me to the King — and farewell all. [Exeunt. Scene III. A room in the Palace. Enter Lady Boleyn. Lady Bol. The crowned falcon now may wing her flight Unscathed by all the arrowy darts of fortune ; Nor hawk nor halloo e'er shall bring her down From her proud perch. My golden wish accomplished, Fate, I defy thee. Enter Rochford. Rochford in good hour ! Our Anne is Queen of England, the King's wife ! Roch. Now Heaven forbid !

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 43 Lady Bol. Out, foolish boy ! hast thou No better greeting for the glorious news That crowns our house with honour? Roch. Ah, poor sister ! Alack, poor Anne ! far better hadst thou died, Than known such baleful honour. Lady Bol. Art thou mad — Have the great tidings stole thy wits away ? Roch. My pulse beat temperately as yesterday, But you, madam, dazzled by false glitter, Spy not the dismal gulf that yawns before us. Think you the King will faithful prove to Anne, When Katharine he forsook ? Lady Bol. The Queen was aged, Ill-favoured grown, had lost the hope to give Male issue to the crown Roch. Anne too must feel The withering touch of Time's rude hand, the sooner For all the carking cares that gird a throne. The King's light love some fairer form may kindle, And Anne be cast aside for the new fancy. Lady Bol. Go to ! forebodings are not proofs — no more, No more of this. Enter Anne Boleyn. Hail, Queen of England, hail ! Anne. Oh, call me not by that ill-omened name.

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act II. 44 Lady Bol. What silly words are these ? Roch. Dear Anne, sweet sister. Anne. Ay, call me by those names ; they are my own And no usurpers. Lady Bol. These are maiden fears. Come, dry thine eyes ; the King must not see tears Upon thy cheek. Anne. I've lost the privilege To weep ! Even as I stood before the altar, Plighting my marriage vows, there rose, methought, On either side, a most majestic form : A queen — a cardinal ! They gazed on me — I quailed beneath their looks, my accents faltered- The King's eye was upon me — oh ! his frown Was terrible. Lady Bol. These are but bridal tremors. Anne. Once on a time a sybil told my fortunes " I should be great beyond all hope, the end Would be most miserable " — so spake she ! Lady Bol. Thou art Queen of England now ; there's not a hair On thy young head the proudest dare to wrong. Be happy then ; the King likes joyous faces. Anne. The Queen must needs seem happy. Roch. Cheer up, Anne. Anne. A step ! It is the King's ! alack, alack !

Scene III.] ANNE BOLEYN. 45 Enter King, Norfolk, Surrey, Gardiner, Sir Thomas Boleyn, Wyatt, and others. King (takes Anne by the hand). My lords, we here present ye this fair lady, Whom we have made the partner of our greatness, The sharer of our throne and state, a consort Most worthy of our love, a queen most worthy Of all our loving subjects' loyal homage. All exclaim. Long live the Queen ! King. We thank ye all, my lieges ! (To Anne) How now — in tears ! Ha ! madam, what is this ? I understand not why women should weep When they are most content. Lady Bol. Pardon, your highness ! The Queen is overcome with her new state. King. I would that it were rather shown in smiles And prompt obedience, than melting showers That mar her beauty. Anne. Heartily I thank them ! My liege, all that I am, your grace hath made me : Your wedded wife — your queen, since it so please you. Duty, obedience, I tender here (kneels). My wishes all henceforth resolve themselves, To your good pleasure, as Heaven may help me !

46 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act II King. Why, this is well. Rise up (raises her) Thou art our queen And lawful spouse. He who shall dare to wag His tongue against thy rights had best look to't, For, by my father's soul, he rues the day. My lord of Norfolk, issue present orders For the Queen's coronation in the Abbey. We long to show our subjects' eager eyes How well Harry hath sped in his fair wooing. Now to the banquet. We will drain a cup In honour of our consort. Thy hand, sweetheart ; We'll lead thee to thy state. All exclaim. Long live Queen Anne. [Exeunt. end of act 11.

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 47 ACT III. Scene I. — A room in the Palace. Enter Surrey and Wyatt. Sur. The times change fast, nor wait the coming hours. The future mocks the past, with a strange semblance. Wy. Hath it already come to this ? poor Queen ! Sur. Who treads o'er roses needs must feel the prick Of thorns. A crown weighs heavily on brows Unused to the dull pressure. Wy. Of late, too, The King affects some touch of jealousy ; As if his truant heart had never wandered, His love as constant as the perfect sun. The new maid of honour, fair Jane Seymour, I do mistrust me, could give some 'count oft. Sur. Ay, and the Queen acts not her part too wisely. She is light of mood, and gives occasion

48 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act III For malice to invent its fatal slanders. Oft have I used a kinsman's privilege To warn her, but in vain ; her humour irks Prudent restraint. Wy. Too much she favours those Beneath her royal state. The minstrel Smeaton Hath grown a malapert. Weston's light speech Hath caused some eyelids wink. At the late jousts Norreys has dared to mount the Queen's device, Nor was reproved for his audacious folly. Anne hath an enemy ever at hand, Who notes down every idle word and gesture, To her undoing. Wy. Think you that the Queen Hath noted the King's love for Mistress Seymour? Sur. 'Twas but last eve she fainted at the banquet. Marking the dalliance that passed between The King and his new minion. He cares not To hide his full-blown passion, which doth gall her To use reprisals, dangerous to her fame. Meanwhile Queen Katharine at Kimbolton Lies sick and like to die. One queen got rid of, Another follows. The road of divorce Once found, 'tis easy travelling o'er again. Nowadays, the world's fashion changes quick. We may soon look to furbish up our robes For a new coronation. The King waits A plea, soon found, to crown another mate.

Scene II. ] ANNE BOLEYN. 49 I'm on my way to audience with the Queen. Wy. I'm summoned to attend on the King's high- ness. [Exeunt, severally. Scene II. — A room in the Palace. Anne Boleyn, Lady Rochford, Smeaton, and Ladies in attendance. Anne (to Smeaton). Wake up thy lute's sweet strains ; even dull sorrow Forgets itself, listening to music's spell. Lady Roch. Sorrow ! a word for subjects, not for queens ! Anne. There's none exempt from grief, or high or low. The canker feeds i' the bosom of the rose. Lady Roch. Canker and grief ! nay, now you mock us, madam. What hath a queen to do with these, save that Time steals away the roses from her cheek, Light from her eyes, strews threads of silver 'mid Her fading tresses ? Anne. Fie ! these are vain toys. Lady Roch. Call you these toys, madam ? Could I bribe Time To spare my charms, I'd queen it o'er the world — Leave care to my dull subjects. E

[Act III. ANNE BOLEYN. 50 Anne. Beauty oft Is but handmaid of folly. Lady Roch. That same beauty Hath won a throne ere now. The King deems not How heavy weighs the crown his love bestowed. Anne. He crowned me queen, but cannot from my heart Take off the burden of the common lot, The cares that all must bear, or queen or peasant. (To Smeaton.) Close Lady Rochford's mocking lips with song. Smeaton sings. What were this world, without the light of love ? A sky without a star ; A desert, whose bright, sparkling fountains prove A mirage from afar ; An idle garden, without fruit or flowers To charm the flying hours. Thine eyes are stars, to light the world below. On thy fair cheek reposes The blushing flowers. Love twines to deck liis brow Love's crown of roses. Love, hovering o'er thy dewy fragrant lips, His fill of nectar sips. Anne. No more of these fantastic verses, boy,

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 51 111 suited for a royal matron's ear. Choose not such theme again, lest we be forced To banish from our presence the deft minstrel. Smea. Madam, never more will I offend. Lady Roch. Nay, please your grace, 'tis but a harm- less lay, Save where it chafe our consciences, or hits Our secret thoughts o' head. Anne. No more of this. Enter Surrey. Ah, cousin Surrey, welcome to our court. Thou hast played truant long. (To Lady Rochford) Leave us. Yet stay — Lord Surrey would read o'er his latest sonnet. Poets are jealous, as the chariest lover, And ne'er forgive a slight offered their muse. I dare be sworn its theme is Geraldine, The fair, mysterious saint of Surrey's worship, Whose name the stars whisper not to the earth, Though oft they must have heard her name invoked. Thou art a churl to hide the secret, coz, But I have vowed to win it from you yet. Sur. 'Tis for your grace's ear alone. Anne (to Attendants). Retire ; Yet leave the door ajar, that Lady Rochford May keep watch o'er us. [Exeunt all but Anne and Surrey.

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act III 52 I could swear at times Her glittering eyes can hear with their swift glances, They follow all the movements of my lips With so much speaking malice. Sur. Call her back ; Provoke not such a foe. Anne. My Lady Rochford, Re-enter Lady Rochford. Lady Roch. Madam, I await your grace's orders. Anne. Wait within this chamber, my Lady Rochford, Lest busy tongues should hint treason is hatched Against the State in conning o'er a sonnet. [Lady Rochford retires to tlie back of the stage. Now, coz, your news ; it should be grave, methinks, To match the cloud that rests on Surrey's brow. Sur. I would unfold a volume to your thoughts, They would do well to scan. Anne. Why, this is strange, Ay, passing strange ! A solemn speech, when I Looked but to hear some pleasant jest should set The jocund hours a-laughing ! Sur. 'Tis no time, Madam, for idle jest — be warned. Anne. Of what ? Speak, Surrey, speak ; I read thy meaning dimly. Has the King's minion dared ? — I am not blind — I know what thou wouldst say — that the King loves

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 53 This Mistress Seymour. 'Tis true then, 'tis true ! Since other eyes than mine have marked his falsehood. Sur. Hush, hush ! speak low : the Lady Rochford's ears Are quick to catch the sounds she lists. Be prudent, Your empire o'er the King may be regained. Anne. Thou know'st him not ; there's but one step betwixt His love and hate — that passed, there's no return For love. Sur. Yield not the field too easily. Anne Boleyn's charms might foil a potent rival. Anne. Alas ! they lack the charm of novelty To his palled fancy, that seeks ever change. Last eve, thou know'st; I fainted at the banquet. 'Twas said the heat o'ercame me — 'twas false, Surrey ; 'Twas not nor heat nor cold surprised my senses. My heart beat lighter than its wont last eve ; I thought to have crushed all suspicion from it. Jane Seymour stood behind me ; leaning forward To answer some gay word of mine, a jewel Fell from her bosom on my hand — and — there It glittered like the eye of basilisk — 'Twas the King's picture, worn around her neck ! Whose hand had clasped it there ? I swooned, and all Cried out, "The Queen is faint for lack of air." Sur. The Seymours are ambitious, and urge on Their sister to the prize.

[Act III. ANNE BOLEYN. 54 Anne. What prize — his love ? Henry's perfidious love ? Well, let her win it. She cannot take the crown from off my head, Nor mount the throne, till I am dead, nor -wrench The sceptre from my hold ! It is no bauble, To pass from hand to hand, like woman's distaff. Sur. Trust not thy rights too far ! Queen Katha- rine leant Upon the reed, it broke and pierced her heart. Anne. Counsel me, Surrey ; I am past all hope. What wouldst thou have me do ? Sur. Above all things, Take heed you give no cause for jealousy ; I' the King's present mood 'twere dangerous. Anne. Hath he a right, who breaks his wedded vows As lightly, as the thief his perjured oaths, All decent feigning laid aside, to 'plain ? Jealous forsooth ! let him take heed the falcon Loose not her jesses to the wind. Sur. Beware ! The game is perilous that you would play. Man in his tyrannous power oft wears his vices Boldly upon his sleeve i' the world's gaze ; Woman should walk ever charily, ay, As if she picked her way o'er burning ploughshares, Nor give a plea to slander, whose base tongue Can tarnish purity itself, which ne'er

Scene II. ] ANNE BOLEYN. 55 Shines forth again with its accustomed lustre — Unlike the mirror, where the sullying breath May come and go, nor leave a stain behind ! Weston has dared to boast he looks to be The King's successor to your hand, when death Shall set you free to wed again. Anne. The coxcomb ! Sur. Norreys at the late jousts assumed your crest. Anne. Well, 'tis no more than custom doth accord The valiant knight who in the lists upholds His sovereign lady's beauty 'gainst the world. Sur. In wanton strains Smeaton breathes his mad passion. Anne. I have rebuked his folly. Must I yield All gentle solace up, clasp hands with grief, Do ghastly penance for another's sins, Renounce the pleasures of my years and state, Bow down my head with sorrow, cross these arms Upon my bosom that can give no ease, Nor yet call death to comfort me ? Sur. Weep not. Enter Wyatt and others. Wy. Queen Katharine is dead at Kimbolton — Pardon, your grace — the Princess Dowager ! Anne. Then am I Queen indeed ! Queen Katha- rine dead ! We well may spare her now the empty title.

56 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act III. The childless mother, discrowned queen ! the King Refused her prayer to see her child — these men Have hard hearts. Queen Katharine dead ! woe's me ! Lady Roch. (aside to Wyatt). The news has ta'en her highness somewhat sharply. Anne. I feel as if the weight of the whole globe Were poised above my head. There, take my crown (takes off the crown) ; It seems too heavy for my brow to-day. Smeaton, a dirge, not for the dead, but living. Smeaton sings. Rest, weary heart, rest from thy sorrow ; Break not to-day, joy comes with the morrow. Darkest night is near the day, Heavy cloud will pass away. After tempest comes fair weather. After dewdrops, roses gather On their leaves a richer bloom, Sweeter scent in their perfume, Brighter for the tears that hung Like diamonds fairy hands had strung ! Rest, weary heart, rest from thy sorrow ; Break not to-day, joy comes with the morrow. Enter King and Attendants. King. Ha ! at your wanton sports, when lamentation Should fill these walls to bursting. Know ye not

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 57 That she lies dead, the best of Nature's all, Most virtuous lady of the universe ; Most loyal, loving wife man was e'er blest with ; The pearl that from our breast we cast away, To wear a counterfeit ? Sur. Sire, spare the Queen. King. A viper stung her mistress unto death. Anne. Ah, me ! King. Ay, weep ! it doth become thee well. Go to thy chamber, minion ; on thy knees Implore the pardon of that saint above For all thy sins. Wear mourning ever, type Of this irremediable woe. Anne. O Heaven, Have mercy on me ! (faints!) Sur. Sire, the Queen is dying. King. Away ; 'tis but a feint to move our pity. Bear her then to her chamber. For awhile Let her not cross our presence. [Exit, attended. Anne (recovering). Where am I ? Is this death, and these the fiends that mock me ? Sur. 'Tis but his highness' mode of speech, when moved To sudden anger ; 'twill soon pass. Cheer up, Madam ; all here are friends. Anne. What was't I heard ? Queen Katharine is dead ! — 'twas Wolsey told me — I thought he had been dead too.

58 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act III. Sur. Her mind wanders. Bear her to her couch ; she needs repose. [Exeunt all but Lady Rochford. Lady Roch. Thy reign is past ; the King loves thee no longer, Anne Boleyn — 'tis my turn to triumph ! Mine, Who was deemed fit to bear my lady's train, So near akin and yet so far apart. [Exit. end of act III.

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 59 ACT IV. Scene I. — A room in the Palace. Enter Surrey and Wyatt, from opposite sides. Sur. Well met ! I sought you in great haste ; you must With me. Wy. Whither ? wherefore ? Sur. The Queen, I fear, Is lost. Wy. The Queen, my lord ! What then hath chanced ? Sur. Yon fatal tournament ! My mind misgave me But evil consequence would follow on't. Strange rumours are afloat, that ever steal Before the march of truth — ill-omened shadows, The boding heralds of a coming woe ! The King broke up the lists most suddenly, From Greenwich in hot haste rode forth, without Leave-taking of the Queen. Confusion dire

[Act IV, 60 ANNE BOLEYN. Hath ta'en the place of order in the palace ; The pages walk a-tiptoe, as afraid, And every straggler of the household comes With boding look and whisper on the lip. I am sent to bid you to the King, Who chafes and rages like a maddened lion. His highness is wrought to such pitch of anger, I dread the issue to the Queen. Who watched The frown that settled on his moody brow, Knew that a tempest gathered in his thoughts. The Queen alone perceived it not, or braved it ; She talked and jested, smiled on all around. At length the storm burst forth. Norreys had gained Some vantage in the fight, and stood at rest, When, leaning o'er the balcony, the Queen Waved her light kerchief, which by chance or choice Fell at his feet. Th' imprudent Norreys raised it, Pressed to his lips, and in his bosom thrust it. The King beheld, and rising from his seat, Took horse to Lambeth, followed by his train. The Council speedily was summoned there, At th' Archbishop's palace. Lady Rochford Is now before it, giving testimony. Her lord, Sir Henry Norreys, Weston, Smeaton, Have been committed to the Tower. 'Tis said That there is matter to attaint the Queen, And that she will be brought to speedy trial. Wy. Poor lady ! she is innocent of all

Scene II.] ANNE BOLEYN. 61 But a light spirit that will not be held In due restraint. Sur. We must delay no longer ; Come then, my barge awaits us at the stairs. [Exeunt. Scene II. — A room in the Palace. Enter Anne Boleyn, Ladies, and Attendants. Anne. Inform the King that I await his pleasure. Dost hear? (to Attendant). Why dost thou loiter? Go at once. [Exit Attendant. The air is stifling in these gloomy chambers. Throw wide the lattice, break it, if needs be, But let the fresh air from the river enter, That fanned my cheek as our barge clave the waters. How mine eyes ache with gazing on the sun ! Blood-red it looked, as it lit up the Abbey, The resting-place of England's noble dead, As if a thousand torches heralded A powerful monarch to repose ; as if It were a palace, not a sepulchre. His warm rays ne'er illume these ghostly chambers ! As I passed through the shadowy corridors, Melhought the portraits of England's dead sovereigns Had more of life in them than painted canvas, As if about to step from out then frames To join me in my walk.

62 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act IV. Re-enter Attendant. What saith his highness ? Shall I attend him in his closet ? At. Madam, His grace is not within. Anne. He takes the air Belike upon the terrace. We will join him. At. He is not on the terrace, please your grace. Anne. Then lead me wheresoe'er he be — fear not The Queen will be your warrant. At. Please your grace, The King is not arrived. Anne. How ! not arrived ? He left Greenwich some time before ourselves. At. His grace alighted from his horse at Lambeth. Anne. Lambeth ! What doth he there, at such an hour? No word to tell us of his sudden purpose. Where is Lord Surrey ? where Sir Thomas Wyatt ? Go, bid them to our presence. At. They have left The palace to attend the King at Lambeth. Anne. Why tarries Lady Rochford ? 'tis the hour For her attendance ; she forgets, methinks, The duties of her office. Lady. Lady Rochford Came not from Greenwich in your grace's train.

Scene IL] ANNE BOLEYN. 63 ■j 'Tis rumoured that the King commanded her Straight to repair to Lambeth. Anne (aside). Lady Rochford At Lambeth with the King ! 'tis passing strange ! Yet have I done no wrong. My foes shall be Abashed. (Aloud) Throw wide the doors, light up the palace ; Let all assume their best array. To-night We hold our court. Where is my brother Rochford ? Where Norreys, Weston ? they should have been here To greet the Queen's return. Go, bid them hither. Bid Smeaton bring his harp ; we'll hear some music. Ye answer me with silence. Must the Queen Speak twice. At. Ma/t please your grace (hesitates) Anne. Why am I left With scant attendance ? Why the dumb confusion Among our household ? Call Lord Rochford ; we Would know the meaning of this strange disorder. At. Lord Rochford is not in the palace, madam. Anne. Is he, too, gone to Lambeth ? Th' Arch bishop Is grown most hospitable all o' sudden. At. Lord Rochford is committed to the Tower. Anne. Oh, my unhappy brother ! At. Weston, Smeaton, Sir Henry Norreys, all are lodged i' the Tower, By warrant from the Council.

64 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act IV. Anne. Sits the Council ? Then take me to it. I will shortly prove The innocence of these poor gentlemen. Enter an Usher. Usher. The Duke of Norfolk, may it please your highness, Sir Thomas Audley, and another are Just disembarked from Lambeth. Anne. They are come To take me to the King. I knew his grace Could not long be wroth with his poor wife. Bring us a mirror quick, that we may smooth Our truant locks. Usher. The duke is at the door, Madam. Anne. Give me my mantle, quick ; this haste Will plead our gracious pardon with the King For our disordered dress. Admit the duke. Enter Duke of Norfolk, Sir Thomas Audley, and Sir William Kingston, who remains in the back- ground. You come, my lord, to take me to the King. I thank him for this pitiful remembrance Of his poor servant — I had great need oft. Nor. We come not from the King. Anne. Not Not from the King !

Scene IL] ANNE BOLEYN. 65 1 Ye come not from the King ? Nor. The Privy Council Despatched us on our errand here. Anne. The Council ! Let them e'er meddle with affairs of State, Nor come between the King and his true consort. Take me to him. Nor. We dare not so offend, Who are his grace's loyal servants. Anne. I, / am no traitor to be dealt with thus. Ah ! now, I see, the malice of my foes Would shut me from his presence, knowing well Mine innocence would confound their schemes. Sir Thomas Audley, take me to the King, I do conjure you, take me to the King. Aud. I pray you, patience, madam. Anne. Patience, patience I should wax faint beneath the burden patience ! Yet promise you will take me to the King, And I will grow a miracle of patience. Ah, me ! who stands within the shadows yonder, Turning his visage from my searching eyes, As if the sight would blind them ? I should know His face, methinks — Sir William Kingston — once I was your guest. Nor. And must be so again, By virtue of this warrant ; the King's pleasure. F

66 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act IV. Anne. The King's pleasure ! Give me the warrant, quick. (Takes the warrant) I cannot read — mine eyes are dim — there now, I've wiped them. Oh, my heart ! the King's name here, No sign of faltering — the King's own hand. There, take it back again — -the lines so waver, I cannot fix their meaning. Prithee tell me. Nor. By virtue of the warrant, we arrest The person of Anne Boleyn, Queen of England — Anne. I thank you for this title, good my lord ; I never thought to hear it more. Nor. Accused Of treason and adultery. Anne. Treason ! Treason ! it were to seek mine own o'erthrow, To meddle in such practices. To plot 'Gainst my own life, fame, throne, where the King's hand Hath raised me, even at his side ! No, no, My lord, the charge is monstrous ! For the rest, Ye call a blush upon my woman's cheek To hear it fall from reverend lips like yours. Nor. Further, you are commanded to the Tower, There to abide during the King's good pleasure. Anne. Is there aught else set down ? Nor. We are commanded

Scene IL] ANNE BOLEYN. 67 To use all proper speed and diligence. Anne. You are my mother's brother, Lord of Nor- folk, Sprung from one body, nursed at one fond breast, Shared the same sports in childhood, prayed together, Laid your young heads together on one pillow. I cannot think that you would come to me On so harsh an errand ! 'Tis but a jest. His highness seeks to prove my love and duty : A cruel jest, and carried out too far. You play your parts right well — throw off your masking, And take me to the King. Nor. Tut, tut ! we trifle ; No more delay, or we shall bear the blame. The barge waits us below. Anne. Sir Thomas Audley, You have no cause to hate me, that I wot of — Speaks the Duke of Norfolk sooth ? Aud. Ay, madam It grieves me much : you are our prisoner, Yet comfort take. Anne. Alas ! 'twas lost to me With the King's favour. Nor. Prove your innocence, And the King's favour will raise you to comfort. Anne. I have sinned much, but not against the King. Subservience to his will is the sole crime

[Act IV. 68 ANNE BOLEYN. My conscience doth lie charged with — but, alack ! The lamb as well might plead its innocence When wolves rush on the fold, or hunted stag When the dogs throttle him. Ah, me ! Anne Boleyn Is now the wrounded deer, all the herd fly from. Nor. No more delay. Anne. I will not keep ye long. Yet I cannot forget I was a queen But now, unused to be commanded thus ; Staying or going at my own sweet will. I fain would take with me some memory To lighten up the gloom of my dark cell. One look, my last, around the regal chambers Where, for three years of empty pageantry, I've played my part — where I have known some hours Of fickle pleasures and deceitful hopes ; Here shed some tears a fond hand wiped away, Chiding my sorrow, that should have been joy. One look on things that daily met my eyes, Familiar grown, till I scarce heeded them. Until about to part ! Wife — mother — queen — And now ! Nor. Tut, tut ! no more of this ! we should Be on our way. Two of your gentlewomen Have leave to wait on you. The Lady Rochford Will join you yonder. Anne. I would have spared her, Who hath ever been my mortal enemy.

Scene II. ] ANNE BOLEYN. 69 My friends (to Ladies), ye who have shared your Queen's good fortunes, Which of ye now will share the evil days She yet may pass on earth? Ladies. Your fortunes, madam, We follow, good or ill. Anne. Thanks, thanks, my friends ! Who says the world is filled with ingrate hearts ? Yet I ne'er took much pains to win your love ; Nay more, I fear I have been fretful oft, Tiring your patience with capricious change ; Arrogant, who should have been all meekness ; Harsh, where I owed forbearance most. I pray ye, Pardon me, for I am humbled now, And never more may in such guise offend. Nor. Come, come. Anne. Oh ! let me see my child once more. Alack ! Queen Katharine died nor saw her child ! Let me but clasp her to my breast once more, Impress a mother's kiss upon her lips, Feel the soft pressure of her little hands, Look in her eyes once more ? She will be taught To scorn her mother — let me see my child, My dove, Elizabeth, my innocent child ? Nor. It cannot be ; it is not in our warrant. Anne. O uncle Norfolk, see, I kneel to thee ! Take pity on me ! think a child of thine May one day kneel to move some flinty heart —

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act IV. 70 Oh, let me see my child ! Nor. Bear her away. Anne. Ye who own pity kneel with me and try To soften this hard-hearted uncle. Nor. Tut ! Lend us a hand, Sir William Kingston, since Force needs must be to bear her to the barge. Anne (rises). Forbear, Sir William Kingston ! we can walk Even the way to death. Farewell, my friends ; Think of me henceforth in all charity, As one of dead and buried 'fore her time. Before the world, in all honest men's judgments, Bear witness to Anne Boleyn's innocence. [Exeunt. Scene III. — A Room in the Tower. Enter Lady Kingston and Messenger. Lady Kings. The Queen's highness coming hither, saidst thou ? Mess. Ay, she is even now upon the way. Lady Kings. Thou bring'st strange tidings, sooth 'twere scarce to credit ! Fallen so soon under the King's displeasure ! The fortunes of this world are ever shifting : The tide ebbing and flowing, as the hours Wear through the night and day. Alack, poor lady !

Scene IV.] ANNE BOLEYN. 71 Thrice happy they who on a lowly pillow May lay their head, nor dread the waking ! Who Waits upon her grace ? Mess. The Duke of Norfolk, Sir Thomas Audley, and Sir William Kingston. They will be here anon, may't please you, lady ; The barge put off in haste. Lady Kings. Alack, alack ! I'll order preparation to be made, Such as the haste admits of, for her comfort. [Exeunt. Scene IV. — A Room in the Tower. Enter Anne Boleyn, Norfolk, Audley, Kingston, Ladies, Guards, etc. Anne (speaks as she enters). But for your timely aid, Sir William Kingston, I should have fallen, climbing the rude steps. Mine eyes were dazzled by the wavering glare Of the fierce torches, the bright flashing halberds. How call you the grim archway where but now We disembarked. Nor. 'Tis called the Traitor's Gate. Anne. Methinks I should have known it ! I re- member That, on the eve before my coronation, The barge that brought me hither, by mischance,

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act IV. 72 Became entangled in the frowning archway, And was with difficulty thence dislodged. I laughed then at the omen, dreaming not To enter there again. Aud. Courage, madam. Omens are idle things, to set at nought. Many have passed through that dark gate to leave These walls again, free from attaint or loss. Anne. How many hath the headsman's arm set free ! How oft hath torture done its slower work ! How oft poison and steel their stealthy task Have done ! Alas ! how oft hath innocence Sent forth the startled cry, justice hears not, Breathed prayers, these pitiless walls have stifled Ere they would reach heaven's vault ! How many died, Self accusation on their perjured lips, Maddened by long captivity and pain ! What if we could see the ghostly tenants That people this dread prison-house ? What if These stones could speak? — Where lies my present chamber ? Is't in some dungeon deeper than the moat ? My hands might well undo your bolts and bars, Or work their way through flinty walls — look to't ! Kings. Your highness will be lodged in the same chamber Where last you slept.

Scene IV. ANNE BOLEYN. 73 Anne. It was a palace then — A prison now ! When last I left that chamber, It was to mount the proudest throne of earth. I was your honoured guest when last I slept Within that chamber — where my bed shall next Be made, these walls may yet discover. Enter Lady Kingston. Lady Kings. Madam, I would fain bid you welcome, but that here 'Twere sorry comfort. Anne. Not so, Lady Kingston ! A prison hath its welcome, like a palace, Though not so cheerily ! All things have welcome, Death hath his welcome, when we lay our griefs And wrongs within his kindly arms to rest. To some death chants a lullaby, as when Our mother's voice crooned o'er our cradled sleep. When death is near, we see the heavens open And hear the angels sing. Kind Lady Kingston, I fear I shall occasion you some trouble For a little while. Lady Kings. 'Twere a great pleasure To wait upon your grace elsewhere. Nor. Our office Being performed, we take our leave. The King Will be impatient to learn our report That all is done as he commanded.

[Act IV. 74 ANNE BOLEYN. Aud. Madam, If there be aught consistent with my duty You would desire, command my humble service. Anne. Commend me to the King, Sir Thomas Audley ; Say that you left me here a prisoner, Submissive to his will, yet sorely grieved Thus to have fallen under his displeasure ; The cause thereof I know not, for the charges Against me published, are too foul and monstrous To be circulated e'en by those who hate me. I humbly do entreat his grace to grant me An audience, when I doubt not to prove My innocence to his full satisfaction. Meanwhile, I do entreat he give no ear To my malicious enemies, who seek To rob me of his favour, who have been — Will ever be — his true and loyal wife, Come life, come death ! Aud. Madam, I will report Your words unto his grace, so help me Heaven ! Anne. Further, if that his highness should reject My prayer to be admitted to his presence, I would beseech him grant me open trial, With access to my friends to counsel me, How best I can make clear mine innocency. So as I have been openly accused, So openly may my defence be heard.

Scene IV.] ANNE BOLEYN. 75 Aud. Trust me, I'll do your bidding faithfully. I take my present leave, praying your grace Speedy deliverance find from all your dole. [Exeunt Norfolk, Audley, and others. Anne. Lead me to my chamber, I am weary. Enter Lady Rochford Lady Rochford ! Lady Roch. Ay, by the King's command, To wait upon your grace. Anne. I could have spared This token of his love ! yet ne'ertheless I thank his highness for his tender care Of his poor wife, though I would rather be Left to my jailer's 'tendance, than employ An idle semblance that but mocks our state — Yet bear we all our crosses as we may. [Exeunt. end of act iv.

76 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act V. ACT V Scene I. — A room in the Tower. Enter Lady Kingston and Messenger. Lady Kings. The trial, then, is ended? In thy looks I read the confirmation of my fears. Mess. Alack ! the judges have pronounced her guilty. The Queen is on her way back to the Tower, The glittering axe turning its cold sharp edge Towards her face, in token of the judgment. Sir Thomas Wyatt comes, who can report More of the trial than I witnessed, lady. Enter Sir Thomas Wyatt. Wy. All is over, and the Queen condemned. Lady Kings. How so ? 'Twas thought pre-contract 'twixt her grace And the Lord Percy would, by rendering null Her after marriage with the King, give plea For absolution of all charges. Wy. Ay,

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 77 So hoped her sanguine friends ; but the twig broke And threw her helpless back into the torrent. The dastard wretch betrayed her in her need. When called upon to certify the contract, He did deny it wholly ; swore that nought E'er passed between them, save light compliments, Such as youth proffers, beauty idly takes, To while away the hour. One word had saved her — His lips have sealed her doom. Lady Kings. Alas ! poor lady. Wy. She had borne up through the day's agony So bravely, that her judges e'en were moved To see such gentle courage. When Lord Percy Took her last prop away, a stifled cry Proclaimed the inward pang. On his pale face Her large dilated eyes she fixed, until He seemed turned into stone beneath her gaze. Lady Kings. Oh, piteous ending to love story ! Wy. When Called on to say if she had aught to urge Against her sentence, calmly she maintained The truth of marriage contract with Lord Percy, Deplored his weakness, yet bestowed forgiveness — So left the court. That fiend, the Lady Rochford, In hate towards her gallant lord, hath by Her perjured testimony, slain the Queen, Laid low the noble gentlemen who lose Their lives to-day together with Lord Rochford.

78 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act V. Hark, hark ! a trumpet sounds the Queen's approach. All strangers are commanded from the Tower, Save those who must enact the tragedy. I'm here to take my last leave of her highness. Lady Kings. Surely the King will ne'er attaint the life Of her, his consort, mother of his child ? A prison were sure refuge for her dole. Wy. There is no prison so secure as death ! Nor tears, nor prayers, nor golden promises Can e'er unlock his fetters. A king's foes Find a safe shelter there from all their terrors. Lo ! the Queen comes. Enter Anne Boleyn, attended ; Sir William King- ston, and others. Anne (speaks as she enters'). Thanks, thanks ! Kind Lady Kingston, We come to plague you for a little while. (Comes forward with Wy att) Wyatt, didst hear him swear my life away ? Wy. I could have struck him in the mouth, the coward ! Anne. Percy, the lover of my youth ! O God ! That there should be such perjured men since Adam ! Would I had died before ! Wy. He is not worthy To be named on your lips — think not of him.

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 79 Anne. How that man seemed to love me once, and when In very wantonness I feigned to doubt, Sent up to heaven such vows of constancy And love, as might have blurred the patient stars ! Wy.
