A wretch forsworn of all, love, honour, truth. Anne. Ah, me ! I read the moral of this world ! The stricken deer must die apart from all The herd, that owned his blithesome fellowship. All the earth seems leagued against me now ! Are these the faces that once smiled on me, Eager to catch my faintest wish ? Is this The earth o'er which I passed treading on roses, The thorns all pluckt, lest they might wound my feet? Where are my flatterers now ? Melted away, Like last year's snow ! Even my sire, my mother, Refuse to see me ere I die — but they Are courtiers ; the King's bounty might stint Itself in presence of such grave offence. The Duke of Norfolk sat among my judges — But uncles are not fathers, that is true ! Enter Norfolk, Gardiner, Surrey, Audley, and others. Nor. We bring the judgment of the court, its sentence. Anne Boleyn, after due deliberation

[Act V. 80 ANNE BOLEYN. i And patient hearing of your cause, the judges Pronounce you guilty of the twofold crimes Of treason and Anne. Halt there, my lord of Norfolk I do appeal against th' unrighteous judgment ! Nor. All in the realm have justice meted to them, Whate'er their state may be. Anne. Call you it justice? Heaven have mercy, then, on all who need it ! Scant justice shall they find at your hands, who Have now condemned me in mine innocence ! Nor. What plaint hast thou ? Anne. Ye did deny me counsel. A woman's tongue lacks eloquence to plead Where life hangs i' the balance, more, her honour ! A woman lacks the wit to ravel out The tangled web of sophistries and wiles The law weaves round its destined victim. Ye Refused to hear my witnesses ; nay, more, Denied me knowledge of the evidence Brought 'gainst me, leaving me i' the dark, whose lips False testimony bore against mine honour, Whom had I known, I had convicted doubtless Of rancorous malice, slanderous abuse. Nor. Tut, tut ! Thou hast had more than even justice. Did I not sit among thy judges, who, Being thy kinsman, needs must weakly lean

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 81 Towards thy favour ? Anne. Now, may Heaven forgive That you did sit among my murderers ! Nor. Tut, tut ! Pass we to the award and sentence : Henceforth, Anne Boleyn, must thou lay aside Title of queen, which thou hast sometime borne ; All privileges, state, thereto belonging, All jewels, robes, to such estate pertaining. All are commanded to forbear towards thee Homage, or service, save such as the law Allows to traitors. Hear ye, hear ye all ! The King in royal mercy doth remit The way of death allotted to your crimes, Of burning, to the milder penalty — The axe and block ! Anne. Rude pillow for the head So lately on his bosom lying ! yet I thank his grace, that he hath spared his wife Some pangs ! You have not named the day and hour? Nor. Ere the first hour of sunrise close — to- morrow — The scaffold and the headsman's axe await thee, And Heaven have mercy on thy soul, Anne Boleyn ! Anne. To-morrow ! That is sudden for such journey For who can quit this earthly tabernacle Without some trembling note of preparation ? The ills of life we know, the thorns that prick us ; G

82 [Act V. ANNE BOLEYN. But what may be beyond the awful threshold Where death keeps faithful watch, none may e'er know Till, that crossed over, there is no return. Who would not fain turn back a little while, Ay, suffer all things here, rather than meet The dread uncertainty of the hereafter ? Who then but must bethink him of some sin Unreconciled betwixt his soul and Heaven, That scares him back to life ? To-morrow ? Nor. Ay, To-morrow, ere the hour of sunrise close ! Anne. And I had much to think of, much to say ; Some friends to take my leave of, some few thoughts To set in writing ; acts of charity, Such as my slender means allow ; to pray Forgiveness on mine enemies, blessings On those who love me, and so take my leave Of this fair world ! Gard. Be reconciled unto The Church, whose doctrines ye have shown despite. Your time of pomp and pleasure is now past. Anne. My lord, you ever were my bitter foe — Yet better than false friend ! I thank your zeal. Gard. The Church hath pardon for the penitent ; Be reconciled to Heaven ! Anne. If sorrow have A claim on heaven, I shall be there anon !

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 83 'Tis only there that we may look for pity ! Man deals harsh judgments on his fellow-man. Though all on earth are sinners, none will pardon The errors of his brethren, as if mercy Shown to another might lose his own soul. Enter Lord Percy. Percy (speaks as he enters). Give way ! I have de- stroyed thee, Anne ! Anne. O Percy ! Percy. I would have died to save the tenderest hair Upon thy head, and yet, I have destroyed thee ! Hear me ! though thou shouldst curse me ever after ! They told me, I should save thee, by forswearing That ever marriage contract passed between us. They told me that the King sought but divorce ; Divorce obtained, they said, thy life were safe. The demon, Lady Rochford, swore such oaths As hell had never heard until she oped Her perjured lips ! Forgive me, oh, forgive me ! Anne. Some say there is such thing as destiny, And that we may not pass our fate ! Ah, me ! 'Tis Heaven measures out the penalty Our sins deserve. This should have I known well ; Who took another's place should look to see Another fill my seat. I must perforce Have sinned to be so punished. I' forgive thee ! Percy. Oh, what a fool was I to be so cozened !

[Act V. 84 ANNE BOLEYN. Anne. Thy presence calls me back to earth once more. Leave me ; thou standest between my soul and Heaven ! Farewell, until we meet above ! Percy. Farewell ! [Exit. Anne. That is well over ! Tell me, I beseech ye, How fare the poor unhappy gentlemen Who lie under the King's displeasure, sharing In my unjust accusal ? Nor. Weston, Norreys, Have already met the doom of traitors. Anne. Can Heaven look down in silence on such murders ? They were most innocent. How died these victims ? Nor. Weston said not a word : Smeaton confessed His guilt. Anne. Then Heaven have mercy on his soul, For he was greatly perjured ! Aud. Spite of torture, Norreys upheld his innocency, died Proclaiming it. Anne. Brave heart ! O, gallant Norreys ! When jousting at the Field o' Cloth of Gold, You fought at the King's side, you dreamed not then He would requite you thus ! — (A gun fired without.) What sound was that ? Kings. The evening gun proclaims the sun is set.

Scene I.] ANNE BOLEYN. 85 Anne. He turns his face from me ! when next we meet In presence, 'twill be on the scaffold. Hark ! A bell mourns his departure with sad tongue ! Nor. It rings the death-knell of a traitor ! Anne. Save us ! Ye said to-morrow ! — who is now to die ? Nor. The villain Rochford. Anne. Rochford ! My dear brother, Thy sole crime that thou wert akin to me ! Bear me to death ; the knife may cleave the air Above my head, mine eyelids shall not wink. I have lived long enough (faints). Aud. The Queen is dead ! Lady Kings. She swoons to hear the dismal news, alas ! (Aside) 'Twere cruel pity to recall her senses Back to this life ; 'twere best that she died now. Sur. (kneels and kisses the Queen's hand). Thus do I take my leave, here pay my homage, AVith deeper reverence than when a crown Circled thy brows with empire, and the hand Which hangs so cold and nerveless at thy side Upheld a sceptre. Nor. Come away, boy, lest The King's displeasure light on us. Tut, tut ! We must not loiter here. Sur. The colour comes

86 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act V. Faintly to brow and cheek — farewell, farewell ! I would not look into her eyes again For all the sovereignty of this fair isle. [Exeunt. Scene II. — The Tower. Anne Boleyn, asleep on a couch ; Ladies in attendance. ist Lady. The morn is breaking. Rosy streaks of light • Flush up the eastern sky. She bade us wake her. 2nd Lady. She sleeps as calmly as a baby still. On her lips a heavenly smile is playing, As if an angel whispered in her dreams. 'Twere pity to awake her — yet we must — The hour draws on. ist Lady. Those ominous sounds again ! Pray Heaven she hear them not ! 2nd Lady. . They drape the scaffold. I see the torches waving to and fro ; Dark forms like demons of the night move round it, As if engaged in some unhallowed rite, To vanish at the peep o' day. ist Lady. Draw close The curtain, lest, awaking suddenly, She see yon object looming 'gainst the sky. She stirs, she wakes. Anne. Where am I ? still on earth ? 'Twas but a dream ! I do remember now. —

Scene IL] ANNE BOLEYN. 87 How goes the night ? I bade ye call me early. 2nd Lady. The sun is not yet risen, gracious lady. Anne. I'll watch him rise for the last time on earth. 2nd Lady. I pray you, go not to the window, madam. Anne. Wherefore ? Think ye mine eyes are dim already ? I would behold the glory of the morn Once more. 2nd Lady. I'll give you timely notice, madam, Of its approach. Anne. Nay, I would watch myself The signs I've hailed so oft with ecstasy, As heralds of another joyous day. I was once sportive as a butterfly. Life seemed but one long festival of glee, — But the night cometh, that shall have no morn ! (Goes to the window) What means yon frowning object i' the court, Round which those ghostly forms are flitting? Ah ! The road that I must travel hence betimes ! It was a pleasant dream anon I waked from. I dreamed I was once more at Hever Castle, In my ancestral halls. On either side There stood an image of my ancestry : A mailed knight, a dame in gorgeous robes. As I gazed on them, they assumed the mien And forms of Wolsey and Queen Katharine.

88 ANNE BOLEYN. [Act V. Folding me in their arms, they gently bore me Away to Paradise ! Call Lady Kingston ; I would speak with her. [Exit Lady, who re-enters with Lady Kingston.] Kind Lady Kingston Thus to come so quickly ; for my sands Are running low. Be seated then, I prithee. Nay, I will have it so. I have a boon To ask on bended knees ; refuse me not — 'Tis a last favour. Lady Kings. Madam, as you please (seats herself). Anne. Thanks, Lady Kingston ! (kneels). In my garish days Of arrogant contentment, oft have I The Lady Mary harshly used, oft chided ; Unkindly with a stepdame's eyes looked on her. She ever did recall her mother to me. I feared she might prove rival of my child For crown and honour, and so I hated her. Now I perceive how gross my fault hath been. When I am dead go to her, Lady Kingston, Kneel at her feet as I do here, show her How humble I became, sue her forgiveness. Lady Kings. Trust me, madam, your pleasure shall be done. Anne (rises). Now can I die in peace ! And yet 'tis hard To quit this warm young life, to be shut out

Scene IL] ANNE BOLEYN. 89 From light and all of nature's glorious aspect. Ay, life is sweet to those about to lose it. When death seems far, far off, we hold our life A petty gift, we make him welcome to At the first cross ; nay, an we prick a finger, Call on death to deliver us from pain, But when he comes, we look askance at him, Praying him tarry for his dues awhile. — Now to adorn us for the ceremony, The last wherein we play our part on earth. Bring here our robes of state, our coronal, The King's first gift — the ruby carcanet. Ay, this is brave attire. Fetch me a mirror. I would once more behold myself a queen, And so take leave of queenship ! I would look Upon the face once hit his dainty fancy. The mirror is no royal flatterer, Gives back the many obligations that I owe his grace ! A private gentlewoman, He raised me up to be a marchioness, From marchioness he made a queen of me. He can no further on this globe advance me, So is about to make a saint of me. 'Twill not give the headsman's arm much trouble To sever this little neck. Enter Norfolk, Gardiner, Kingston, Guards, etc. Nor. What mean these gauds ?

ANNE BOLEYN. [Act V. 90 Woman, thou wert forbid to wear the emblems Of state which is no longer thine. Gard. Throw off The idle gear, and think of thy soul's welfare. Anne. Patience, Lord Bishop, and good uncle Norfolk ! The King could ne'er be wroth that I should take One look on all that he hath done for me : This crown, these robes, that decked me for his pleasure. My cheek is paler, true, than once it was ; My eyes less bright, my brow less smooth. The gifts I owe his grace I would pay back with thanks ! Now help me to undress and make me ready For the brief journey I must undertake. My crown I do bequeath to Mistress Seymour ; This ruby carcanet to my successor ; These royal robes are not yet frayed or dulled By use, may serve another coronation Nor. Tut, tut ! 'tis time we moved. Anne. Bear testimony, All ye who hear me ! I die innocent Of all the heavy sins laid to my charge. Albe't perhaps I have not always borne me As humbly towards my lord the King as was My duty, seeing he had raised me up From low estate to be his queen and consort. Say to his care I do commend our daughter

Scene II. ] ANNE BOLEYN. 91 t (Cranmer did prophesy great things of her); Also, I do commend my faithful servants Unto his kingly bounty, for my means Too scanty are to satisfy their needs. My last thought is for him — Enter Lady Rochford. Thou here ! Lady Roch. Ay, madam. My duty claims attendance to the last. Anne. You have shaken the glass, my Lady Roch ford, Till the last sand is nearly spent — enough ! Death has its privileges, and waves back Revenge from yonder threshold — cross it not ! I would go forth to meet my doom, without The shadow of thy presence, that would darken The face of death himself ! [Exeunt all but Lady Rochford. Lady Roch. Farewell, Anne Boleyn The hour of sunrise draws to speedy close. end of act v.

ANNE BOLEYN. 92 EPILOGUE. Scene. — Richmond Park. Enter King, Lords Beauchamp, Ferrers, Hunts men, etc. King. The sun is grown a laggard, keeps his bed, When he should be afoot to brush the skies. Wind a reveil shall shake the clouds about His ears ; he hath o'erstayed his reckoning. [Huntsmen sound their horns. It were a blast to wake old Pluto's dogs If they were winking — yet he tarries still ! Lo ! i' the east, behold the rosy streaks That herald his approach ; yet he shows not His jocund visage to the morn, that waits A-tiptoe for his smile. Why loiters he To-day, of all the days of all the years ? So ho ! a merry stave to chide his staying !

ANNE BOLEYN. 93 Chorus of Huntsmen. The ban-dog in his kennel sleeps, The wolf hath sought his lair ; The blind mole to his dark home creeps — He scents the morning air. The screech-owl to his roast is gone, In the lone ruined tower ; The bat clings to the ivied stone Of beauty's crumbling bower. The adder stirs him in his coil ; The toad stares at the day ; The spider weaves his wary toil To catch his fluttering prey. And life and death run on their race, One loses and one wins, Through night and day — may Heaven's grace Assoil us of our sins ! King. Ye croak like ravens o'er unburied corse. Enough ! this were no strain to charm the ear Of dainty Phœbus ; he would list as well The screech-owl's song, the scream of wounded bat. But lo ! he comes, peering above the trees, With round face leer, as curious to discover What hath been done on this half o' the globe While he was toying with the other side.

94 ANNE BOLEYN. Ferrers. See how the gossamers float on the air, Like winged fairies at their elfin sports ; On every blade of grass there hangs a drop, As if the stars were weeping o'er the day. King. Here on this knoll we'll stretch our limbs and watch His gambols through the trees. My lord of Beau champ, Have you no tale, to while away the hour ? We are in mood to listen to a jest. Beau. A sorry jest 'twould be, my gracious liege, From my untutored lips, that can discourse Of hearty blows, parry and thrust, hacked limbs ; The right down honest give and take of war. No words have they for fancy's honied food. King. Ever the same bluff warrior, Lord Beauchamp, With tongue as rough as ever licked a cub Into its proper shape. No flatterer thou, Albe't we hold thee as King Hal's true servant. Beau. My arm is yours, my liege, but not my tongue, That hath no silvery eloquence of speech, And needs must wag in its unseemly fashion. Plain Beauchamp is no carpet knight to sit AVith arms and legs crossed, sighing out his soul To the soft din of lute or dulcimer. King. We hold you well excused from such mild pastime.

ANNE BOLEYN. 95 Come, sit you down. Tush, man ! the emerald turf No velvet carpet is, as you will find By the rough proof, no pillow for the head Would rest on down, whate'er poets may sing. Lord Ferrers, you have been a traveller ; Doubtless from foreign lands, where you sojourned, Brought homeward many a strange and moving tale ; The traveller's privilege to sport with truth ; At sober firesides cause men stare to hear The world should hold such monstrous sights and shapes, Such direful incidents, such comic passes, That make the salt rheum gather in our eyes, Or shake our sides with laughter. Ho ! a tale, My lord of Ferrers, one to lure Titania From jealous watching of her Oberon. Fer. My liege, but little skilled in love am I, But if a plain unvarnished tale King. Tush, man, Begin ! Excuses are for ladies' lips, Who dally o'er what e'en they like the best : To hear themselves discourse. Fer. Sire, I obey ! In Provence, the fair garden of the South, Where yet the bloom of Eden seems to linger, As if reluctant to depart for aye ; — Where the proud palm tree waves its graceful head, The dark pine lifts its haughty crown, whose leaves

96 ANNE BOLEYN. Strew aromatic odours on the ground ; — Where the green cork tree climbs the rugged steeps ; The olive, tree of moonlight called, distils Food for the midnight lamp of sage or lover, Or beacon star to guide the mariner When the low vesper bell hath rung its chime ; The giant cactus with its gorgeous flowers, That seem to set the air aflame around ; — Where stately aloes fringe the shores — the tree So strange, so mystical, that, like true love, Blossoms but once a lifetime ; the blue sea Is mirror to the sky, which like a sapphire Bends over all ! Where the gold orange glows 'Midst the cool emerald leaves, whose starry flowers Scent the soft air like breath of paradise ; The rich pomegranate with its burning flowers, That make the eyelids droop to gaze on them, Like passionate thoughts that flash through poets' dreams, Hangs out its fruit, within, all orient gems ; The almond blushes at the spring's first kiss ; Pink oleanders make a wall of bloom, To shade deep violets, gay hyacinths, The silver lilies, the sad, rich tuberose ; — Where the rose wins another name of beauty ; * * Lord Ferrers is here misinformed. The rose usually called the rose of Provence takes its name from Provins, a town in the north of France, whither it was transplanted from Palestine.

ANNE BOLEYN. 97 Where love's own flower, the fragrant myrtle, nestles As it would hide from the sun's wanton gaze, In nooks and shady corners of the heights ; — Land of the troubadour and "Gentle Tongue !" — In Provence, on a lofty peak that formed A rocky link in a long chain of hills, A castle frowned, whose stubborn ramparts oft Had stood th' assault of roving Saracen ; An old grey town crouching low at its base, Girded with towers and stalwart walls, that linked The fortress to its gates. From the high turrets The eye looked forth upon the distant sea (More distant than it seems, so clear the air), Beyond the fairy isles that stretch their arms To guard the bay from the waves' boisterous sport And o'er the range of hills, that farther west Fence the rude ocean from the smiling plain ; The last one crowned upon its eastern brow With venerable hermitage, resort Of pious pilgrims : where the mariner, Escaped from perils of the deep, hangs up His votive offering, pours forth his thanks In prayer before Our Lady's holy shrine. O'er a wide valley, with its orange trees, Vines, where the rich grapes cluster i' the sun Like gems of topaz, purple amethyst. Yet as sorrow mingle th with all mirth, As life sees death for ever in its path, H

98 ANNE BOLEYN. I for- The dark-leaved cypress rears its mournful aspect, Whose shadow darkens earth like open grave — That gloomy tree round which the serpent coiled When Eve was tempted and death gained a world The towers are ruins now, but nature smiles As kindly as when in the castle dwelt Sir Gilles de Barbe, a knight who well had fought In Palestine for Holy Rood ; 'twas said Had brought from thence dark lore of things bidden By mother Church. King. Beshrew me, but the Church Was ever. busy. Well, proceed. Fer. 'Twas said He knew the secrets of the alchemist : To turn the baser metals into gold, To lengthen life beyond its natural span, Prolong youth's power and beauty in man's frame ; Could brew love-philtres to enthral coy hearts, Call up the fiends, question futurity, Ay, and compel an answer ! I vouch not The tale is true, but so 'twas told to me, My liege. King. A wondrous tale ! and, by Our Lady, We marvel not the Church kicked somewhat at it. She' loves no miracles but of her making. Fer. Deep in the night a lamp was ever burning In the high chamber of the eastern tower,

ANNE BOLEYN. 99 Where none might enter save Sir Gilles himself. 'Twas there he wrought, 'twas said, his charms and spells, Held converse with the demons, hell gaped forth To do its vassal's bidding. He had given To hell a bloody bond, his soul the forfeit, The Devil would claim at the appointed hour. Yet otherwise the knight differed not much From others of his wealth and quality. Jocund of mood, could feast with appetite, Laugh at a jest, share in the gay carouse, Listen to minstrel's harp and troubadour, (That oft came wandering to his castle-gate), Nor showed a cloven foot, when i' the saddle He vaulted nimbly ; comely, too, of mien He was. King. Tush, man ! 'tis only ignorance That paints the Devil with grim horn and hoof ! He is a comely gentleman, beshrew me, Or Eve had never listened to his jargon. What saith my lord of Beauchamp ? Ha ! he sleeps, And by his visage, dreams a troubled dream. Rouse thee, Lord Beauchamp. Beau. Pardon, good my liege, I slept methought somewhat uneasily. King. Lord Ferrers' ghostly tale blent with your slumbers, As a low dirge oft runs throughout our dreams,

100 ANNE BOLEYN. Whose strain is but the whining of some beggar Suing for alms beneath our window. Now The sequel of the tale, whose eloquence Beguiles the sun to loiter on his way. Fer. Thus passed the years without a cloud, save one. Childless, alas ! was still Sir Gilles de Barbe ; No son had he to carry on his line, Nor hope of one, his lady waxing old. One day, he called her to the eastern turret, From whence she staggered forth, breathless and pale. From that hour peaked and pined away. Some said She had inhaled a poisonous vapour there, Or seen some horrid sight ; but others said Her malady was but a broken heart, For words that he had spoken of divorce Betwixt them twain ! Suffice, the lady died. Within a month, Sir Gilles brought home a dame Buxom and fair, his newly wedded spouse ; And for a year the cloud seemed passed away. One year ! the lady brought a daughter forth. The knight swore long and loud, but still no help. A puling girl, when boys were so much wanted ! Another year, no promise of an heir — And now the cloud loomed darker than before. One eve, one summer eve, the sun not set, The lady to the eastern tower must wend, And ne'er came forth again. Upon the morn,

ANNE BOLEYN. 101 Was at its base found dead. By some 'twas thought, Gazing from the high lattice at the sun, Dazzled she fell. Some shook their heads, nay, whispered That a strong arm had hurled her down below. But there was no mistake— her neck was broken. Once more the dark cloud seemed to pass away ! One month, and the knight brought a new spouse home, A meek and lovely damsel. In a year The gentle lady on her couch lay dead ; But no dark cloud above the castle rested ! A boy was worth the price she paid — her life ! So deemed the knight, as with high pomp and state The youthful lady to her rest was borne. The heir crowed on his nurse's knee — Sir Gilles Went forth to woo and win another bride. King. What, take a fourth ? a second Solomon But that we doubt his wisdom on this score. Three were enow for any man o' conscience. We interrupt the tale, a pleasant one. Marry, we yet may learn how Gilles de Barbe Contrived to help himself to a fifth mate. Dost hear Lord Beauchamp ? tush, he sleeps again ! Ferrers. Men marvelled this time that Sir Gilles brought home A bride nor young nor fair, as they who slept At peace within the old ancestral vault. h 3

102 ANNE BOLEYN. But the young heir crowed on his nurse's knee, And men hoped that the cloud had passed for aye ! One night — 'twas but three months since she was wed — The lady to the eastern tower was called. She came not — she had fled, in convent cell Had found sure refuge ; none knew why. Sir Gilles Was forced to sue the Church to grant divorce, Ere he brought home a young and beauteous lady In place of her, his disobedient spouse, Who would not quit the cloister for his bed, And so perchance her life preserve — some thought. The bride was blithesome, gay, and debonair ; Loved mirth and jollity, toyed with the pages. Askance Sir Gilles looked on the wanton game. The more she toyed, the darker grew the cloud ! 'Twas noon ; the knight was in the eastern tower, Whither the lady went. 'Twas thought he called her. The day was sultry, a storm i' the air. The crash of thunder shook the battlements, And with it blent, and yet above it rose, A fearful cry, as of lost soul in pain ! Without the threshold of the eastern tower, The lady on the floor was lifeless found ; Around her slender throat a strange blue mark, As if some fiendish hand had grasped her there. They buried her out of sanctuary, Like thing accurst — and the cloud passed away.

ANNE BOLEYN. 103 Brief was the wooing next, speedy the nuptials. In a short week Sir Gilles brought home a spouse, Widow of knight who fell in Palestine. She was a goodly lady and devout — Would bring, 'twas hoped, a blessing on the house. But day by day the cloud waxed dark and darker, Till it o'erspread the castle with its gloom. Some whispered 'twas a sign the time drew nigh The knight's soul would be forfeit to the bond ; Yet day by day went by, and each alike. 'Twas night, some minutes wanting to the hour When evil spirits have power o'er the earth, The hour, Sir Gilles with laugh and jest had bidden The lady meet him in the eastern tower. The cloud grew black as midnight without stars ! The lady to the gruesome tryst had gone, The holy book clutched in her hand, a charm Hung round her neck, relic of martyred saint. Who saw her pass noted her cheek was blanched, But not with fear, her step as firm as aye. Scarce had the eastern door closed on her, when A long loud peal of thunder rocked the castle. The tower from top to base was rent in twain. The body of the knight was never found ; Whether it lay beneath the ponderous ruins, Or, as some held, the demon claimed his own, Body and soul, at the appointed time, The knight failing to render in his toils

104 ANNE BOLEYN. As many victims as the bond required, To loose Sir Gilles from the dread penalty — None knew, nor e'er have known. The lady spake not Of aught that she had seen or heard that night. The young heir from that moment peaked and pined ; He crowed no more upon his nurse's knee — And the dark cloud for ever passed away. Castle and lands the lady, with her hand And heart, bestowed upon a worthy knight. The pair lived happy ; dying, left then wealth Unto the Church — may Heaven assoil their souls ! So ends the story of Sir Gilles de Barbe ; The peasants call him still " Barbe Bleu," in proof That he had won and lost so many wives. King. Gramercy for the tale — a pleasant one, Albe't the knight proved but a fool at last, To be outwitted thus. Why, God a' mercy ! An Eve had been a widowed gentlewoman, The Devil himself would have been amort. — Lord Ferrers, lo ! what see you i' the east ? Are my eyes dazed with looking on the sun ? Ferrers. My liege, I see a dark cloud weighing down From heaven, as it would crush all light below. King. More to the left, man, of the frowning blot Which darkens the fair river with its shadow ; A bright spot waving 'gainst the sky. Look, look ! 'Tis the proud banner of old England's state,

ANNE BOLEYN. 105 That hails the morn from Cæsar's lofty tower. Hush !— hark ! — that sound ! (Gun is heard!) So ho ! the deed is done, The deed is done ! Rouse up, rouse up, Lord Beau champ ; Uncouple the hounds and away ! To horse, Good gentlemen ! Brave sport ! the King himself Will sound reveil, run down a nimble doe. Methinks I have good appetite for breakfast. (Aside) So ho ! the deed is done, the deed is done ! To-morrow we will wed with Mistress Seymour ! [Exeunt. the end.
